The 'University of Cambridge' (informally known as "'Cambridge University'" or
simply as "'Cambridge'") is a public research university located in Cambridge,
England, United Kingdom. It is the second-oldest university in the English-
speaking world (after the University of Oxford), and the third-oldest surviving
university in the world. In post-nominals the university's name is abbreviated
as Cantab, a shortened form of Cantabrigiensis. Note: Cantabrigiensis is an
adjective derived from Cantabrigia, the Latinised form of Cambridge. It is
considered to be one of the most prestigious institutions of higher learning in
the world. {{cite news |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/cambridge-
named-as-best-university-in-the-world-2349326.html |title=Cambridge named as
best university in the world |newspaper=The Independent |date=5 September 2011
|accessdate=April, 2013 |first=Alison |last=Kershaw}}

The institute grew out of an association of scholars that was formed in 1209,
early records suggest, by scholars leaving Oxford after a dispute with
townsfolk. The two "ancient universities" have many common features
and are often jointly referred to as [[Oxbridge]]. Today, Cambridge is a
collegiate university with 31 colleges and six academic schools. All these
university institutions occupy different locations in the town including purposely-
built sites and the student life thrives with numerous opportunities in the
arts, sport clubs and societies. Cambridge is also a member of many academic
associations and forms part of the 'golden triangle' of British
universities. A total of 89 Nobel Prizes winners are affiliates of
the university. The official count excludes researchers at the MRC
Laboratory of Molecular Biology after 1962 without a college or university
affiliation. (See separate listing).
categories: Educational institutions established in the 13th century
